answers: I sold my house and had been in the market looking for a replacement house for over 6 months after I sold it. I found someone willing to give me a short term, 3 month lease, with a month to month after that, at an equitable rate, as renters were scarcer than buyers.By the time I found a house, there were bidding wars as surplus had declined (can be caused seasonally), and it was quite difficult to get my new house. However, appraisers help this to a degree because whatever the seller wants, is not necessarily what they get, even if you offer it. Of course I had to be prepared if it came in higher, but I did my homework and knew pretty much what the house was worth. The mortgage is the same as the lease I had, the house is only 10 years' old and has a 1 year warranty on large items that could go wrong. If I am claiming 0 dependents I will get back about $5,000 this year versus breaking even.

2. Impact on credit utilization ratio: When you receive a new card with new account numbers, the outstanding balance on your old card is generally transferred to the new card. High credit utilization can negatively impact your credit score, so it's important to keep your utilization ratio low.

The impact of replacing a lost credit card on your credit score will depend on various factors, including the length of your credit history, the type of credit you have, and the overall health of your credit profile. In general, the effect is usually minor and temporary, and your credit score will most likely return to normal within a few months after the new card is issued.

To minimize the impact on your credit score, you
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically exclude withheld taxes, also known as dividend withholding taxes or foreign taxes withheld on dividends. These taxes are deducted by the U.S. company paying the dividend and are not reflected in the dividend quote itself.

The dividend quote you receive will represent the gross dividend amount, which is the amount of money you will receive before any taxes are withheld. The amount of taxes withheld will depend on your individual tax situation and the tax laws of your country of residence.

For example, if you are a non-U.S. investor holding U.S. stocks, you may be subject to U.S. withholding taxes on dividends paid out by the company. The amount of taxes withheld will depend on the tax treaty between your country of residence and the United States, as well as your individual tax situation.

It is important to note that some U.S. companies may choose to pay dividends gross, meaning they will not withhold any taxes, but this is less common. In general, it is important to consult with a tax professional or financial advisor to understand how dividend withholding taxes may affect your individual situation and to ensure you are in compliance with all applicable tax laws.
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

Is it possible to block previously authorized ACH access?[/INST]
pred:
As a financial assistant, I can inform you that it is generally not possible to block previously authorized ACH (Automated Clearing House) access once it has been established. ACH payments are digital payments that are transferred between banks and are handled by the National Automated Clearing House Association (NACHA).

When a business or individual sets up ACH payments, they typically grant the payee (the person or business receiving the payment) authorization to access their bank account for a specific purpose, such as regular monthly payments or one-time payments. This authorization is typically granted through an agreement or contract that outlines the terms of the ACH payments.

Once the ACH payments have been authorized, the payee can initiate the payments by submitting payment instructions to the payer's bank. The bank then verifies the payment instructions and transfers the funds to the payee's bank account.

While it may be possible in some cases to cancel or reverse an ACH payment, it is generally not possible to block previously authorized ACH access. This is because the ACH network is designed to facilitate the efficient and secure transfer of funds between banks, and the payee has already been granted authorization to access the payer's bank account.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Does the low CAD positively or negatively impact Canadian Investors?[/INST]
pred:
A low Canadian dollar (CAD) can have both positive and negative impacts on Canadian investors, depending on their individual circumstances and investment strategies.

Positive impacts:

1. Export-oriented businesses: A low CAD can make Canadian exports cheaper and more competitive in foreign markets, potentially leading to increased sales and revenue for businesses that rely on exports. This can have a positive impact on the overall economy and create new investment opportunities.
2. Tourism and travel: A low CAD can make Canadian destinations more attractive to foreign tourists, potentially leading to increased tourism and travel spending. This can have a positive impact on local economies and create new investment opportunities in related industries such as hospitality and transportation.
3. Investment in U.S. assets: Given the historic relationship between the CAD and the U.S. dollar (USD), a low CAD can make Canadian investors more competitive in U.S. markets. This can lead to increased investment in U.S. assets such as real estate, stocks, and bonds.

Negative impacts:

1. Import costs: A low CAD can increase the cost of imported goods, potentially leading to higher prices for consumers and reduced purchasing power. This can have a negative impact on consumer spending
answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is the point of the stock market? What is it for, and why might someone want to trade or invest?[/INST]
pred:
The stock market serves as a platform for buyers and sellers to exchange ownership claims on publicly traded companies. Essentially, individuals and organizations buy and sell small parts of these companies through shares, known as stocks. prompt:

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
Stop-loss is a risk management technique used to limit potential losses in a trading portfolio. It involves selling a security at a predetermined price, known as the stop price, when the security reaches that level. The stop-loss order is designed to limit potential losses by automatically closing a position at a predetermined price, thereby preventing further losses beyond that point.

Whether using stop-loss is safe depends on various factors, including the trader's risk tolerance, trading goals, and market conditions. Here are some pros and cons to consider:

Pros:

1. Risk management: Stop-loss orders can help traders manage their risk by limiting potential losses. By setting a stop price, traders can minimize the risk of incurring large losses if the market moves against them.
2. Emotional control: Stop-loss orders can help traders avoid making emotional decisions based on short-term market fluctuations. By setting a predetermined stop price, traders can remove the emotional factor from their decision-making process.
3. Protection of capital: Stop-loss orders can help protect traders' capital by limiting the amount of losses they can incur. By setting a stop price, traders can minimize the amount of capital they can lose if the market moves against them.

Cons:

1
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

Yes, another tax loss can be used to offset capital gains taxes through a process called "loss harvesting." Loss harvesting involves selling an investment at a loss to offset capital gains from other investments or to reduce your taxable income.

Here's how it works:

1. Identify investments that have experienced a loss: Review your investment portfolio and identify investments that have declined in value and are worth less than you paid for them.
2. Sell the loss-making investments: Sell the investments that have experienced a loss, and use the proceeds from the sale to offset capital gains from other investments.
3. Use the loss to offset capital gains: You can use the loss to offset capital gains from other investments, such as stocks or mutual funds. For example, if you have $1,000 in capital gains from the sale of another investment, you can use a $1,000 loss from another investment to offset those gains.
4. Carry over the loss: If the loss exceeds the amount of capital gains you have to offset, you can carry over the remaining loss to future years. You can use this carryover loss to offset capital gains in subsequent years, potentially reducing your tax liability.
5. Keep in mind the wash sale rule: It
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

High frequency trading (HFT) is a trading strategy that leverages powerful computers, sophisticated algorithms, and low-latency connections to execute trades at extremely high speeds. HFT firms typically hold trades for very short periods of time, sometimes milliseconds, and use leverage to amplify their returns.

When an HFT firm sells a security, it typically does so with the expectation of buying it back quickly at a lower price, pocketing the difference as profit. However, there may be situations where the firm cannot access the funds it needs to buy back the security within the expected timeframe, such as when the markets are closed or when there are technical issues.

In these situations, HFT firms may use a concept called "rehypothecation" to continue trading. Rehypothecation is the practice of using securities as collateral to obtain loans from other parties, such as broker-dealers or other financial institutions. By using these securities as collateral, HFT firms can access the funds they need to continue trading without having to liquidate their entire portfolio.

Yes, a debt collector is generally allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report when attempting to collect a debt. A hard inquiry occurs when a creditor or debt collector requests access to your credit report in order to verify your creditworthiness or to collect a debt.

The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) allows debt collectors to obtain a copy of your credit report for the purpose of collecting a debt. This means that they can make a hard inquiry on your credit report without your explicit consent, as long as they are acting within the scope of their legitimate business purposes.

However, it's worth noting that debt collectors are required to follow certain guidelines when making inquiries on your credit report. They must provide you with a clear and conspicuous disclosure that they are making a hard inquiry on your credit report, and they must also obtain your written consent before doing so.

It's important to be aware of the Rule on hard inquiries, as multiple hard inquiries within a short period of time can have a negative impact on your credit score. This is because credit scoring models consider multiple inquiries in a short period of time to be a sign of increased credit risk, and they may result in a lower credit score.

In summary, a debt collector is generally allowed to make a hard inqu
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

A stop order, also known as a market stop order, is an order to buy or sell a security when it reaches a certain price, known as the stop price. On the other hand, a stop limit order is an order to buy or sell a security when it reaches a certain price, but only at a specific price level. Unlike a stop order, a stop limit order will not be executed if the security reaches the stop price but does not trade at the specified price level. This means that investors using a stop limit order will not be filled at a price lower than the limit price they have specified.

answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

This involves buying or selling a financial instrument that is inverse to the expected movement of the related asset. answers: In this type of strategy profit is made when the shares go down as your main position is the short trade of the common stock. Yes, there is a concept that is the opposite of dollar-cost-averaging, and it is called "lump-sum investing" or "lump-sum withdrawal."

Dollar-cost-averaging is a strategy where an investor invests a fixed amount of money at regular intervals, regardless of the market conditions. This strategy helps to reduce the impact of market volatility on investments by spreading the investments over a period of time.

On the other hand, lump-sum investing involves investing a large sum of money at one go, rather than investing smaller amounts at regular intervals. This strategy is generally considered high-risk because it exposes the investor to the market fluctuations in a single go, rather than averaging them out over time.

While dollar-cost-averaging can help to reduce the risk of investing, lump-sum investing can offer some benefits, such as:

1. Potential for higher returns: When the market is at a high point, investing a lump sum can result in higher returns than investing smaller amounts at regular intervals.
2. Reduced timing risk: When the market is at a high point, investing a lump sum can minimize the risk of missing out on potential gains.
3. Simplified investment planning: When an investor has a

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible instruments are financial instruments that can be converted into another security, typically equity. The four options you mentioned - debt, note, bond, and debentures - are all different types of convertible instruments, but they have some similarities and differences.

Debt refers to a financial obligation that the issuer must repay the holder, usually with interest. A debt instrument, such as a bond or loan, is a type of debt security that represents the amount borrowed and the interest rate paid to the lender. Debt is generally considered a fixed-income investment, and the interest payments are typically made semi-annually or annually.

A note, on the other hand, is a type of debt security that has a fixed maturity date and a fixed interest rate. Notes are typically issued by companies to raise capital, and they can be secured or unsecured. Unlike bonds, notes do not have a fixed income stream and typically do not have a fixed repayment schedule.

A bond is a type of debt security that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower, typically a corporation or government entity. Bonds have a fixed income stream and a fixed repayment schedule, and they can be secured or unsecured. Bonds are considered a fixed-income investment and typically offer a fixed interest rate and a fixed m
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

To qualify for this deduction, the taxpayer must meet certain criteria:

1. The taxpayer must be away from their regular workplace for more than a temporary period, such as a few days or weeks.

The amount of the rent deduction will depend on the taxpayer's actual costs, such as the rent for the temporary housing, utilities, and other expenses incurred while living out of town. The taxpayer should keep accurate records of these expenses and include them on their tax return.

answers: There are certain situations where you could legally pay yourself rent, but it'd be in the context of multiple business entities interacting, never in the context of an individual renting their own property.  Even if you could, any rent paid to yourself would count as rental income, so there'd be no benefit. Edit: I was hunting for examples where it might be acceptable, and didn't, but I found a good explanation as to why it is not acceptable from Brandon Hall on a BiggerPockets post: To get technical, you will be going up against the Economic Substance   Doctrine which states that a transaction has economic substance if:   (1) the transaction changes in a meaningful way (apart from Federal   income tax effects) the taxpayer’s economic position; and (2) the   taxpayer has a substantial purpose (apart from Federal income tax   effects) for entering into such transaction. By transferring your primary residence into a LLC, you would not be   changing your economic position. Further, you do not have a   substantial purpose for entering into such transaction other than to   simply avoid paying federal income taxes. So it might make sense if multiple people owned the LLC that owned the property you wanted to rent, and there are instances where company X owns holding company Y that owns an office building that company X rents space in. But if you're the sole player in the LLC's then it sounds like a no-go.

answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there).  Carl Icahn for example is one of those investors in Apple's case [and in many cases!] who put significant pressure, particularly when they were sitting on hundreds of billions of dollars. Ultimately, a (for-profit) corporation's board is tasked with maximizing its shareholder's wealth; as such, it can buy back shares, pay dividends, sell the company, liquidate the company, or expand the company, at its discretion, so long as it can justify to its shareholders that it is still attempting to maximize the value of their holdings.  Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

answers: A huge amount of money in all financial markets is from institutional investors, such as mutual funds, government pension plans, sovereign wealth funds, etc.  For various reasons these funds do all of their trading at the end of the day.  They care primarily that their end-of-day balances are in line with their targets and are easy to audit and far less about "timing the market" for the best possible trades. So, if you're looking at a stock that is owned by many institutional investors -- such as a stock (like AAPL) that makes up a significant portion of an index that many funds track -- there will be a huge amount of activity at this time relative to stocks that are less popular among institutions. Even just in its introduction this paper (PDF) gives a fair overview of other reasons why there's a lot of trading at end-of-day in general. (In fact, because of all this closing activity and the reliance on end-of-day prices as signposts for financial calculations, the end-of-day has for decades been the single most fraud-ridden time of the trading day.  Electronic trading has done away with a lot of the straight-up thievery that floor traders and brokers used to get away with at the expense of the public, but it still exists.  See, for example, any explanation of the term banging the close, or the penalties against 6 banks just last month for manipulating the FX market at the close.)

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Can an ETF perform differently than its holdings?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, an ETF (Exchange-Traded Fund) can perform differently than its holdings in several ways:

1. Rebalancing: ETFs are required to rebalance their portfolios periodically to maintain their target weights, which can lead to differences between the ETF's performance and the performance of its underlying holdings. For example, if an ETF tracks a particular index, but the index experiences a sudden change, the ETF may need to sell some of its holdings to rebalance its portfolio, potentially leading to a different performance outcome.
2. Trading costs: ETFs are traded on exchanges, and the buy and sell prices may differ from the net asset value (NAV) of the ETF. This can lead to differences between the ETF's performance and the performance of its underlying holdings, especially for smaller or less liquid ETFs.
3. Management fees: ETFs are managed by a fund manager, who may take a fee for their services. This can lead to differences between the ETF's performance and the performance of its underlying holdings, especially if the management fees are high.
4. Creation and redemption spreads: ETFs are created and redeemed through a process called creation and redemption, which involves buying and selling large blocks of securities to and from authorized participants.
answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

As mhoran_psprep said, some of it goes to pay interest to the depositors; some of it goes to pay the bank's expenses like employee salaries, cost of the building, etc; and some of it goes as profit to the owners or stockholders of the bank. If you're thinking, "Wow, I'm paying back a whole lot more than I borrowed", well, yes. But remember you're borrowing that money for 20 or 30 years. The bank isn't making very much money on the loan each year that you have it -- these days something like 4 or 5% in the U.S., I don't know what the going rates are in other countries.

How do UK Gilts interest rates and repayments work?[/INST]

UK Gilts are a type of government bond issued by the UK Treasury to raise funds from investors. When you buy a Gilbert, you are essentially lending money to the government for a fixed period of time, and in return, the government pays you a fixed rate of interest known as the yield. The yield is determined by the market forces of supply and demand, and it can fluctuate over time based on various economic factors.

The interest rate on Gilts is generally fixed for the duration of the bond's term, which can range from 5 to 30 years. For example, a 10-year gilt might have an interest rate of 1.5% per annum, which means that you will receive 1.5% interest on your initial investment every year for the next 10 years.

The repayment of the principal amount at the end of the bond's term is also fixed, and it is known as the redemption price. The redemption price is higher than the original issue price, and it takes into account the interest payments made over the life of the bond. For example, if you buy a 10-year gilt with a redemption price of £100 and an initial issue price of £90, you will receive £10 in interest payments over the next 10 years, and at the end of the term,
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

answers: A UTMA may or may not fit your situation. The main drawbacks to a UTMA account is that it will count against your child for financial aid (it counts as the child's asset). The second thing to consider is that taxes aren't deferred like in a 529 plan. The big downside to the 529 is the 10% penalty if the money isn't used for higher education. In the United States, the tax year for gifts is generally the calendar year, meaning that gifts given in a particular year are considered tax-deductible for that year. This means that gifts given in 2022 will be considered tax-deductible for the tax year 2022.

The IRS sets a annual gift tax exclusion, which is adjusted for inflation, and gifts up to this amount do not have to be reported or taxed. For the 2022 tax year, the annual gift tax exclusion is $15,000 per recipient. This means that you can give up to $15,000 to as many individuals as you want without having to pay gift tax or report the gifts. Any gifts above the exclusion amount will be subject to gift tax, and gifts above $25,000 to any one recipient will also be subject to Generation Skipping Transfer Tax (GSTT).

It is important to keep track of the gifts you give throughout the year, as well as the value of each gift, in case you need to report them on your tax return. You should also be aware of any special rules or limits that may apply to certain types of gifts, such as gifts to spouses, gifts to charity, or gifts made through trusts or estates.
answers: Based on past case law, a check made payable to qualified charity and delivered (e.g., placed in the mail on 12/31 would count as delivered as it is out of the hands of the donor) would fall under the "constructive receipt doctrine". However, for non-charitable gifts (e.g., gifts to family members) it is the date the check is cashed (honored by the receiving bank).  This is important as the annual gift exclusion is just that "Annual".  Therefore, if I gift my child $14,000 by writing a check on 12/31/2014 but they deposit it on 1/3/2015 then I have used my annual gift exclusion for 2015 and not 2014.  This means I could not gift them anything further in 2015. BTW the annual gift amount is for ALL gifts cash and non-cash.  Most people don't seem to realize this.  If I give $14,000 of cash to my child and then also give them Christmas gifts with a value of $1,000 I have exceeded my annual gift exclusion to that child.  Usually there are ways around this issue as I can give $14,000 to each and every person I want and if married my spouse can do the same.  This allows us to give $14,000 from each of us to each child plus $14,000 from each of us to their spouse if married and $14,000 from each of us to each of their children if they have any.

The ask price is the lowest price at which a security can be bought or sold. It represents the price at which the seller is willing to sell the security. This strategy is known as "dollar-cost averaging." By consistently purchasing securities at the bid price or below, investors can minimize the impact of market volatility on their investments.

For example, let's say you want to invest $10,000 in a particular stock. Instead of purchasing the stock at the ask price, which may be $50 per share, you could purchase it at the bid price, which is $45 per share. This would allow you to buy
answers: This sometimes happens to me. It depends on how liquid the option is. Normally what I see happening is that the order book mutates itself around my order. I interpret this to mean that the order book is primarily market makers. They see a retail investor (me) come in and, since they don't have any interest in this illiquid option, they back off. Some other retail investor (or whatever) steps in with a market order, and we get matched up. I get a fill because I become the market maker for a brief while. answers: The price of the last trade... Is the price of the last trade. It indicates what one particular buyer and seller agreed upon. There is absolutely no requirement that one of them didn't offer too much or demand too little, so this is nearly meaningless as an indication of what anyone else will be willing to offer or demand. An average of trades across a sufficiently large number of transactions might indicate a rough consensus about the value of a stock, but transactions will be clustered around that average and the average itself moves over time. Either you offer to sell or buy at a particular price, wait for that price, and risk the transaction not taking place at all if nobody agrees, or you do a spot transaction and get the best price at that nanosecond (which may not be the best in the next nanosecond). Pick the one which comes closest to your intent and ignore the fact that others may be getting a slightly different price. That's just the way the market works. Investing in dividend-yielding stocks with money borrowed from a margin account can be a lucrative strategy for investors looking to generate passive income. However, it's essential to understand the risks involved and the potential consequences of leveraging your portfolio.

When you invest in dividend-yielding stocks using a margin account, you are essentially borrowing money from the broker to purchase more shares than you could otherwise afford with your cash reserves. The dividends earned on these stocks are then used to pay off the borrowed amount, plus interest charges.

The benefits of this strategy include:

2. Faster growth: With a margin account, you can invest more money in a shorter amount of time, potentially leading to faster growth in your portfolio.

However, there are also significant risks involved, including:

1. Risk of margin calls: If the value of your portfolio falls below a certain level, your broker may issue a margin call, requiring you to deposit more money or sell some of your shares to cover the borrowed amount. This can lead to significant losses if
answers: In addition to the other answers, here's a proper strategy that implements your idea: If the options are priced properly they should account for future dividend payments, so all other things aside, a put option that is currently at the money should be in the money after the dividend, and hence more expensive than a put option that is out of the money today but at the money after the dividend has been paid. The unprotected futures (if priced correctly) should account for dividend payments based on the dividend history and, since maturing after the payment, should earn you (you sell them) less money because you deliver the physical after the dividend has been paid. The protected ones should reflect the expected total return value of the stock at the time of maturity (i.e. the dividend is mentally calculated into the price), and any dividend payments that happen on the way will be debited from your cash (and credited to the counterparty). Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, the wash sale rules are different for stocks, exchange-traded funds (ETFs), and mutual funds. The wash sale rules are intended to prevent investors from abusing the tax laws by claiming losses on investments they have sold at a loss and then repurchasing the same or substantially identical securities without incurring a substantial time period between the sale and repurchase.

For stocks, the wash sale rules are straightforward. If an investor sells a stock at a loss and buys the same stock (or substantially identical stock) within 30 days before or after the sale, the loss is disallowed for tax purposes. This is known as a "wash sale." The disallowed loss can be added to the cost basis of the new stock, and the investor can only claim the loss when they sell the new stock.

ETFs and mutual funds are treated differently under the wash sale rules. Unlike stocks, there is no 30-day look-back period for ETFs and mutual funds. Instead, the IRS uses a "substantially identical" test to determine whether a wash sale has occurred. This means that if an investor sells an ETF or mutual fund that tracks a particular index, and then buys a different ETF or mutual fund that tracks the same index within 3
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical." pred:
Biweekly mortgage payments have gained popularity in recent years as a way for homeowners to save money on interest and pay off their mortgage faster. However, there are some potential catches to consider before adopting this payment schedule.

Firstly, biweekly payments are not the same as making one extra payment per year. When you make a biweekly payment, you are dividing your monthly payment amount into 26 payments per year, rather than the standard 12. This may seem like a minor difference, but it can have a significant impact on your loan term and total interest paid.

For example, let's say you have a $200,000 mortgage at a 4% interest rate. Your monthly payment amount would be $963.91 ($200,000 x 4% x 12). However, if you make biweekly payments of $453.91 ($963.91 ÷ 26), you will end up making 26 payments per year, rather than the standard 12. This means you will pay off your loan faster and save more in interest over the life of the loan.

However, there are some potential downsides to consider. Biweekly payments may require more financial discipline than traditional monthly payments

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing, although they are both important financial metrics used in real estate investment analysis.

Capitalization rate, also known as cap rate, is a financial metric that helps investors determine the potential return on investment for a real estate property. It's calculated by dividing the property's net operating income (NOI) by its acquisition cost or value. The cap rate represents the percentage return on investment based on the property's income-generating potential. A higher cap rate indicates a higher potential return on investment, while a lower cap rate suggests a lower potential return.

Net profit margin, on the other hand, is a financial metric that helps investors measure the profitability of a real estate investment. It's calculated by dividing the property's net operating income (NOI) by its total revenue. The net profit margin represents the percentage of revenue that converted into profits after deductions, such as operating expenses and debt service. A higher net profit margin indicates a more profitable investment, while a lower net profit margin suggests a less profitable investment.

prompt:

How much is one “lot” of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
One "lot" of EUR/USD refers to the standardized amount of euros or US dollars that can be traded in a single transaction on a financial exchange. The size of a lot varies depending on the exchange and the currency pair being traded.

For example, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME), the standard lot size for EUR/USD is 100,000 units of the base currency (euro). This means that if you want to trade one lot of EUR/USD, you would need to exchange 100,000 euros for US dollars.

However, it's worth noting that traders can also trade fractional lots, which are smaller than a standard lot. For example, a trader may choose to trade a 0.1 lot of EUR/USD, which would be equivalent to 10,000 euros for US dollars.

The size of a lot is important to consider when trading currencies because it can affect the amount of money you need to deposit in your trading account, as well as the potential profit or loss on each trade. Trading larger lots can also increase the potential profit, but also increases the risk of larger losses.

In summary, one "lot" of EUR/USD refers to 100,000 units of
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]

Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) are a type of equity compensation that employers issuing to employees as a way to incentivize and reward employees for their services. RSUs are taxed differently than traditional stocks and can be subject to different tax implications depending on how they are handled by the employee and the employer.

In general, RSUs are taxed as ordinary income to the employee when they vest, which means the employee is taxed on the fair market value of the units at the time they vest. This is because the employee is considered to have received taxable income equal to the fair market value of the units at the time they vest. However, when the RSUs are sold, the employee may be eligible to pay long-term capital gains taxes if they have held the units for more than one year.

The tax implications of RSUs can be complex and depend on various factors, including the type of RSUs granted, the terms of the plan, and the employee's individual circumstances. However, in general, RSUs are not taxed as long-term capital gains unless the employee has held the units for more than one year.

A check is a type of payment method that involves transferring funds from one bank account to another through a check. When a check is written, the issuer instructs their bank to pay the specified amount to the payee. The check is then forwarded to the payee's bank, which verifies the account balance and deposits the funds into the payee's account.

Checks can be invalidated in several ways:

1.Stop payment: The issuer can place a stop payment on a check by notifying their bank in writing. Once a stop payment is placed, the bank will not honor the check.
2.Account closure: If the issuer closes their account, the check may become invalid as the account no longer exists.
3.Insufficient funds: If the issuer's account does not have enough funds to cover the check, it may be returned to the payee as invalid.
4.Dated checks: Checks with expired dates may also be considered invalid.
5.Revoked check: If the issuer revokes a check, it may become invalid.

answers: A subsidy is a payment made by a group (usually the state) to individuals or corporations in order to shift the balance if the rational economic decision for the individual would be detrimental to the group as a whole otherwise. Is it a bad idea to buy a motorcycle with a lien on it?[/INST]
pred:
Buying a motorcycle with a lien on it can have both advantages and disadvantages. A lien is a legal claim on a property for the purpose of securing a loan, and when you buy a motorcycle with a lien, the lender retains ownership of the title until the loan is paid off. Here are some factors to consider:

Advantages:

1. Lower upfront costs: Buying a motorcycle with a lien can help you lower your upfront costs, as you may be able to obtain financing with a lower down payment.
2. Flexibility: With a lien, you can still use the motorcycle as collateral for other loans or credit products, such as a personal loan or a line of credit.
3. Protection: If you default on your loan, the lender can repossess the motorcycle, potentially avoiding financial loss.

Disadvantages:

1. Loss of equity: When you buy a motorcycle with a lien, you may not have complete ownership of the vehicle, which means you could lose equity in the motorcycle if its value decreases over time.
2. Higher interest rates: Lien loans often have higher interest rates than traditional loans, which can increase the overall cost of the motorcycle over its lifespan.
3. Risk of repossession: If
answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is the meaning of “short selling” or “going short” a stock?[/INST]
pred:
Short selling, also known as "going short" a stock, is a trading strategy in which an investor borrows shares of a stock from a broker and sells them at the current market price, with the expectation of buying them back at a lower price later and profiting from the difference. This strategy is used to profit from a decline in the value of the stock, rather than a rise.

When an investor short sells a stock, they are essentially betting that the stock will decline in value. The investor borrows the shares from a broker and sells them at the current market price, then buys the same number of shares back at a lower price, returning the borrowed shares to the broker and pocketing the difference as profit.

For example, let's say an investor believes that the stock price of XYZ Inc. will decline. They could short sell 100 shares of XYZ Inc. by borrowing the shares from a broker and selling them at the current market price of $50 per share. If the stock price does decline to $40 per share, the investor can buy 100 shares of XYZ Inc. back at the lower price and return the borrowed shares to the broker, pocketing a profit of $10 per share or $1,000 total.
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

These graphs are commonly used by financial professionals, investment advisors, and individual investors to evaluate the potential risks and rewards of different investment strategies.

One of the most commonly used ROI vs risk graphs is the Rule of 100, which plots the expected return of an investment on the vertical axis and the level of risk on the horizontal axis. The Rule of 100 states that for every 1% of risk taken, an investor can expect to earn a return of around 10%. This means that investments with higher potential returns typically come with higher levels of risk, while those with lower potential returns are generally less risky.

Another useful ROI vs risk graph is the Rule of 114, which is similar to the Rule of 100 but takes into account the time value of money. This graph plots the expected return of an investment on the vertical axis and the level of risk on the horizontal axis, but also includes a time dimension to account for the fact that money grows more rapidly over time due to the power of compounding.

prompt:

Why would a tender offer be less than the market price?[/INST]
pred:
A tender offer is a financial move made by a company or individual to acquire a certain number of shares from its shareholders at a predetermined price. The price offered is generally below the current market price, and there are several reasons why this might occur:

1. Cost savings: The company or individual making the tender offer may aim to acquire shares at a lower price than the current market price to save money on acquisition costs. By paying a lower price, they can minimize the amount of money they need to pay out to shareholders, which can increase their profitability.
2. Value investing: The tender offer may be part of a value investing strategy, where the company or individual believes that the shares are undervalued in the market. By acquiring shares at a lower price, they can profit from the difference between the acquisition price and the intrinsic value of the shares, which they believe will increase over time.
3. Risk management: The company or individual may be looking to reduce their exposure to potential losses associated with holding shares in a particular company. By acquiring shares at a lower price, they can minimize their potential losses if the share price were to fall further.
4. Strategic reasons: The tender offer may be part of a larger strategic plan, such as consolidating the company's ownership or gaining control over a particular industry or market.
answers: As an addition to Chris Rea's excellent answer, these tender offers are sometimes made specifically to cast doubt on the current market price. Now, what happens when investors lose confidence in a stock? They sell it, supply goes up, demand goes down, and the price drops. The company making the tender offer can then get its shares either way; directly via the offer, or on the open market. This is, however, usually not successful beyond the very short term, and typically only works because the company making a tender offer is the 800-pound gorilla, which can dictate its own terms with practically anyone else it meets. Such offers are also very closely watched by the SEC; if there's any hint that the larger company is acting in a predatory manner, or that its management is using the power and information of the company to profit themselves, the strategy will backfire as the larger company finds itself the target of SEC and DoJ legal proceedings.

VAT (Value Added Tax) is generally not applied when a tradesman charges for materials, as long as the tradesman can provide proof that they have purchased the materials from a VAT-registered supplier. This is because VAT is only charged on the value added to goods or services at each stage of the supply chain, and the tradesman is generally not considered to be adding value to the materials they purchase from a VAT-registered supplier.

For example, let's say a plumber purchases a box of pipes from a VAT-registered supplier for £100. The plumber then uses these pipes to complete a job for a customer, and charges the customer £150 for their services. In this case, the plumber would only be charging the customer £50 for their services (£150 - £100), as the £100 for the pipes has already included VAT at the standard rate of 20%.

However, if the tradesman is not able to provide proof that they have purchased the materials from a VAT-registered supplier, then they may be liable for charging VAT on the value of the materials they use in their work. This is because VAT is generally charged on the value of goods or services provided in the course of a business, and the tradesman would be
answers: The plumber will apply for and receive a refund of the amount of VAT he paid on the purchase amount.  That's the cornerstone of how VAT works, as opposed to a sales tax.  So for example: (Rounded approximate amounts for simplicity) Now, at each point, the amount between (original cost VAT) and (new VAT) is refunded.  So by the end, a total of £3 VAT is paid on the pipe (not £6.2); and at each point the business 'adding value' at that stage pays that much.  The material company adds £1 value; the producer adds £4 value; the supplier adds £5 value; the plumber adds £5 value.   Each pays some amount of VAT on that amount, typically 20% unless it's zero/reduced rated.  So the pipe supplier pays £1 but gets a £0.2 refund, so truly pays £0.8.  The plumber pays £3 (from your payment) but gets a £2 refund.   So at each level somebody paid a bit, and then that bit is then refunded to the next person up the ladder, with the final person in the chain paying the full amount. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Will the popularity of index funds cause a pricing bubble in the stocks that make up an index?[/INST]
pred:
The popularity of index funds has led to increased demand for index-based investment products, which has in turn driven up the prices of the stocks included in many indexes. This phenomenon is sometimes referred to as a "pricing bubble." However, it's important to note that the relationship between index fund popularity and pricing bubbles is complex and can depend on various factors.

Firstly, the popularity of index funds has led to increased liquidity in the market, which can make it easier for investors to buy and sell stocks. This increased liquidity can lead to higher prices as more investors clamor to get their hands on a particular stock. However, this increased liquidity does not necessarily create a pricing bubble. In fact, the increased liquidity can actually help to smooth out price fluctuations and reduce volatility in the market.

Secondly, the construction of many indexes is based on market-capitalization weighting, which means that the largest companies in the index have a disproportionate influence on the overall performance of the index. As a result, when investors pour money into index funds, they are often buying up the shares of the largest companies, which can drive up their prices. This can lead to a pricing bubble if investors become overly enthusiastic about these stocks and bid up their prices beyond their true value.
answers: With regard to commodity futures, a paper released in January 2010 by Aulerich, Irwin, and Garcia, concluded that index funds have essentially no impact on commodity futures. Looking at stocks, a stock that gets included in a major index does increase in price. It increases its turnover by 27% and increases its price by between 2.7% and 5.5%, according to information cited by Kula in this paper, though it looks like the price increase tends to happen in the lead up to the stock being included. Interestingly, I have read an article but cannot now locate it, which states that there's a measurable, albeit fairly small, price bubble on stocks included in common indexes, on Monday mornings, Friday afternoons, and at the start and end of the month. That is, the times when mutual funds are most likely to rebalance their holdings. This almost certainly applies to a lesser extent to other stocks, too. My understanding is that the price difference was very small, however. Generally speaking, stocks which make part of well-known indexes will tend to be in higher demand than stocks which do not. It remains the case that almost all actively-managed mutual funds are unable to consistently beat the indexes, even with this taken into account.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How to distinguish gift from payment for the service?[/INST]
pred:
Distinguishing between gifts and payments for services can be a challenge, especially in a business setting. Here are some key factors to consider to help you make this distinction:

1. Intent: Consider the intent behind the payment. If the payment is made with the intention of showing appreciation or goodwill, it may be considered a gift. On the other hand, if the payment is made in exchange for a service, it is generally considered a payment for that service.
2. Value: Determine the value of the payment in relation to the service provided. If the payment is significantly higher than the value of the service, it may be considered a gift. Conversely, if the payment is consistent with the value of the service, it is likely a payment for that service.
3. Transfer of ownership: Consider whether the ownership of the item or service being provided is being transferred to the recipient. If the ownership is being transferred, it is generally considered a payment for that service.
4. Recognition: Consider whether the payment is being made in recognition of a service provided. If the payment is being made in recognition of a service, it is generally considered a payment for that service.
5. Tax implications: Consult with a tax professional to determine the tax implications of the payment. In some cases, a payment may be considered a gift, but have tax implications that are similar to a payment for a service.
answers: Most people will never need to pay federal gift taxes. The federal gift taxes start after giving away 5.34 million over the course of your life. This number is adjusted annually for inflation. There are only two states that I know of which impose state gift taxes (Connecticut and Minnesota); in Connecticut, you need to start paying taxes if the lifetime value of your gifts exceed two million. In Minnesota, it starts at 1 million.  The federal tax is paid for by the person making the gift, unless other arrangements are made. There is an annual exclusion amount of approximately $14,000. You can give up to this amount to any number of recipients and it is not considered taxable. Therefore, when you give $100 to someone, it is not a taxable event.  If you do make a gift to an individual in excess of 14k, you'll need to file a gift tax return (IRS Form 709). When you file form 709, you won't need to pay taxes until the 5.34 million is exceeded. Instead, you can claim an exemption. Since most people don't exceed that amount, its rare to ever pay taxes even when exceeding the annual exclusion amount. The annual exclusion amount is adjusted each year for inflation.

This principle is known as the "year of accrual" rule, which means that taxes must be paid based on the tax laws in effect when the taxes were earned or accrued, rather than when they were paid.

There are some exceptions to this rule, such as when the taxpayer files an amended return or makes a claim for refund within a certain time period after the original return was filed. In these cases, the taxpayer may be able to retroactively apply tax laws that were enacted after the original return was filed, but this requires careful planning and documentation to demonstrate that the amended return or claim for refund was filed within the allowed time frame.

The opposite of an economic bubble is generally referred to as a "stable" or "sustainable" economy. In an economic bubble, prices or assets rise rapidly and unsustainably due to excessive demand or speculation, leading to a burst or crash. In contrast, a stable economy is characterized by a more gradual and sustainable growth in prices and asset values, driven by fundamental factors such as strong economic fundamentals, sound monetary policy, and a balanced economy.

A stable economy is generally defined by several key characteristics:

1. Slow and steady economic growth: Economic growth is consistent and sustainable, rather than experiencing sudden and unsustainable increases.
2. Low inflation: Prices rise gradually and at a moderate pace, rather than experiencing sudden and sharp increases.
3. Strong economic fundamentals: The economy is driven by a strong foundation of factors such as a skilled workforce, sound infrastructure, and a well-functioning financial system.
4. Prudent monetary policy: Central banks are able to manage the money supply and interest rates in a way that promotes economic stability and sustainable growth.
5. Balanced economy: The economy is balanced between different sectors, such as industry, services, and agriculture, and is not overly dependent on any one sector.
6. Low levels
answers: The opposite of an economic bubble is a bubble burst :p! Jokes aside though, an economic bubble occurs when the economy is in bull market mode and asset prices are growing very fast. It's usually measured by ratio's like price to earnings and the levels of various market indices. So, the opposite would be when valuations are falling very fast or are very low, and price to earnings ratios are low.  This condition is usually a recession. A recession is a market slowdown, generally after a bubble bursts, and severe recessions can become depressions if they last long enough (Great Depression, 1930s).  A bubble is not necessarily negative - stock prices usually rise a lot so paper wealth is greatly magnified. If you can get out in time, you're golden. Similarly, a recession isn't bad for everyone. Some investors keep large amounts of cash waiting for recessions so they can "buy low, sell high". For most people, however, recessions are negative because unemployment increases and some people get fired, and the economy slows down. Asset prices have fallen so their investments are worth less than they used to be (on paper), and people mainly have to bide it out until the market starts growing again.

Yes, the bid price of a stock can change depending on which brokerage you are using. The bid price is the highest price that a buyer is willing to pay for a security at a given time, and it can vary depending on a variety of factors, including the brokerage firm's market making or trading costs, the level of liquidity in the market, and the overall demand for the security.

Different brokerage firms may have different bid prices for the same stock due to their unique pricing structures and the way they operate in the market. For example, a discount brokerage firm may have lower bid prices than a full-service brokerage firm due to their lower operating costs and lack of other services such as financial planning and investment advice.

Additionally, the bid price can also vary depending on the type of order you are placing. For example, a market order, which is an order to buy or sell a security at the current market price, may have a different bid price than a limit order, which is an order to buy or sell a security at a specific price you set.

A dividend "will not be quoted ex" means that the company will not pay a dividend for a particular period, usually a quarter or a year. This term is commonly used in stock market announcements and financial reports to inform investors of the company's decision not to pay a dividend for a specific time.

When a company decides not to pay a dividend, it may be due to various reasons such as:

1. Conservation of cash: The company may choose to retain its profits instead of distributing them as dividends to reinvest in the business, pay off debts, or build up cash reserves.
2. Financial instability: The company may be going through a rough financial period and may not be able to afford dividend payments.
3. Capital expenditures: The company may be planning to invest in new projects or equipment, and may not want to divert funds from dividend payments.
4. Risk management: The company may be trying to manage its risk by not paying dividends, especially during times of economic uncertainty.

It is important to note that the lack of dividend payments does not necessarily mean that the company is in financial trouble. Many companies choose to reinvest their profits to grow their business, and the lack of dividend payments does not necessarily indicate financial distress.

answers: One occastion where "will not be quoted ex" is used is when a corporate action is occurring such as a spin-off.  In such a case, the rights to, and the spin-off itself may be quoted separately on the home country exchange.  However, if the company is based abroad, it may not be worth the expense for them to have an additional securities listing on the local (US) exchange. prompt:

What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transferred or sold to another party through a legal document, such as a certificate or a check. These securities are typically issued by companies or governments to raise capital, and they can be traded on financial markets. Negotiable securities are considered negotiation instruments because they can be delivered to a third party through a legal process called negotiation, which involves endorsing and depositing the security in a financial institution.

Derivatives, on the other hand, are financial contracts that derive their value from an underlying asset or group of assets. Derivatives can be used to hedge against potential losses or to speculate on price movements of the underlying asset. They can take many forms, including options, futures, and swaps.

Negotiable securities and derivatives are related in that they can both be used to manage financial risk. For example, a company may issue a negotiable security to raise capital, and then use the proceeds to hedge against potential losses by entering into a derivatives contract. Alternatively, a company may issue a derivative instrument, such as a futures contract, to lock in a fixed price for an underlying asset, such as commodity.

In summary, negotiable securities are financial instruments that can be transferred or sold to another party through a legal document, while derivatives are financial contracts that derive their
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.

You can deposit money into your TFSA at any time, and the interest earned on that money is not taxed.
